issue.title: STL Decomposition Error after upgrading to version 0.14.0
issue.body:
#### Describe the bug


My application uses STL from statsmodels.tsa.seasonal to perform Time-Series Decomposition. It works perfectly when I use the version of statsmodels==0.13.2, but when I upgraded to version 0.14.0 it throws a ValueError on the endog.


<details>

```python
>>> from statsmodels.datasets import co2
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> from pandas.plotting import register_matplotlib_converters
>>> register_matplotlib_converters()
>>> data = co2.load().data
>>> data = data.resample('M').mean().ffill()
>>> from statsmodels.tsa.seasonal import STL
>>> res = STL(data).fit()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "statsmodels/tsa/stl/_stl.pyx", line 212, in statsmodels.tsa.stl._stl.STL.__init__
  File "/home/miguel/.local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/statsmodels/tools/validation/validation.py", line 147, in array_like
    raise ValueError(msg)
ValueError: endog must have ndim <= 1

</details>


#### Expected Output

I would expect the STL to perform without throwing "ValueError: endog must have ndm <=1"

#### Output of ``import statsmodels.api as sm; sm.show_versions()``

<details>

dashboard_1  | INSTALLED VERSIONS
dashboard_1  | ------------------
dashboard_1  | Python: 3.8.16.final.0
dashboard_1  | OS: Linux 4.15.0-96-generic #97-Ubuntu SMP Wed Apr 1 03:25:46 UTC 2020 x86_64
dashboard_1  | byteorder: little
dashboard_1  | LC_ALL: None
dashboard_1  | LANG: C.UTF-8
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | statsmodels
dashboard_1  | ===========
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | Installed: 0.14.0 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/statsmodels)
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | Required Dependencies
dashboard_1  | =====================
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | cython: 0.29.21 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/Cython)
dashboard_1  | numpy: 1.20.0 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/numpy)
dashboard_1  | scipy: 1.5.0 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/scipy)
dashboard_1  | pandas: 1.4.3 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pandas)
dashboard_1  |     dateutil: 2.8.2 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/dateutil)
dashboard_1  | patsy: 0.5.3 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/patsy)
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | Optional Dependencies
dashboard_1  | =====================
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | matplotlib: 3.7.1 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/matplotlib)
dashboard_1  |     backend: agg 
dashboard_1  | cvxopt: Not installed
dashboard_1  | joblib: 1.3.2 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/joblib)
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | Developer Tools
dashboard_1  | ================
dashboard_1  | 
dashboard_1  | IPython: Not installed
dashboard_1  |     jinja2: 3.1.2 (/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/jinja2)
dashboard_1  | sphinx: Not installed
dashboard_1  |     pygments: Not installed
dashboard_1  | pytest: Not installed
dashboard_1  | virtualenv: Not installed

</details>

comment.body:
> You can call `squeeze()` as a workaround when passing 2d data.

Thank you for your reply.  But the same data with the same format works for both seasonal_decompose and the new MSTL statsmodels.tsa.seasonal methods.

commits.message: TST: Relax tolerance on random failure

DOC/REG: Improve documentation

Add release note
Fix some small doc issues
Allow squeezable into STL

closes #9042

pull_request.title: Backport 0.14.1
pull_request.body:
- [ ] closes #xxxx
- [ ] tests added / passed. 
- [ ] code/documentation is well formatted.  
- [ ] properly formatted commit message. See 
      [NumPy's guide](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.15.1/dev/gitwash/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message). 

<details>


**Notes**:

* It is essential that you add a test when making code changes. Tests are not 
  needed for doc changes.
* When adding a new function, test values should usually be verified in another package (e.g., R/SAS/Stata).
* When fixing a bug, you must add a test that would produce the bug in main and
  then show that it is fixed with the new code.
* New code additions must be well formatted. Changes should pass flake8. If on Linux or OSX, you can
  verify you changes are well formatted by running 
  ```
  git diff upstream/main -u -- "*.py" | flake8 --diff --isolated
  ```
  assuming `flake8` is installed. This command is also available on Windows 
  using the Windows System for Linux once `flake8` is installed in the 
  local Linux environment. While passing this test is not required, it is good practice and it help 
  improve code quality in `statsmodels`.
* Docstring additions must render correctly, including escapes and LaTeX.

</details>

issue.title: python3.11 support in 0.14.0 ?
issue.body:
In 0.13.5 , python 3.11 is documented as supported:

https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/v0.13.5/setup.py#L100-L105

but it's not in 0.14.0

https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/v0.14.0/setup.py#L100-L103


For reference, python 3.11 was added in 0.13.5 tag with this commit maintenance/0.13.x branch that is not on main branch
https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/commit/d8c880a4760f6df544c1454189cbb3f4ed13954f#diff-60f61ab7a8d1910d86d9fda2261620314edcae5894d5aaa236b821c7256badd7R104

If 0.14.0 supports python 3.11, I believe it's better to mention it in setup.py. Thanks !

issue.title: ENH: Leybourne-McCabe stationarity test
issue.body: Hi SM - I started looking at stationarity again and forgot that I have a nice implementation of Leybourne-McCabe stationarity test (https://github.com/JimVaranelli/Leybourne-McCabe) which I'm happy to PR if there is any interest. AFAIK, Matlab is the only other implementation which was used for unit test verification. For usability I added an empirical autolag procedure as well as allowing for the possibility of zero lags. MC-derived CVs are also provided. Further details are in the readme.

comment.body:
FYI - just issued pull request #9039 for this

https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/pull/9039

issue.title: ENH: MNLogit identification with categorical variables
issue.body:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77352027/mnlogit-summary-return-a-array-with-a-lot-of-nan

My guess would be that if we have categorical variables, then we need observations for each endog/exog-cat cell.
But I'm not sure what identification condition we need.

possible workaround:
add option `hessian_pinv=True` to use pinv for hessian that is only semi-definite but not positive definite.

comment.body:
This might be a separation case for nonexistence of MLE

Cook, Scott J., John Niehaus, and Samantha Zuhlke. “A Warning on Separation in Multinomial Logistic Models.” Research & Politics 5, no. 2 (April 1, 2018): 2053168018769510. https://doi.org/10.1177/2053168018769510.

"standard" solution is Firth penalization, but other penalization might be better (in some cases, as in Logit)

Beiser-McGrath, Liam F. “Separation and Rare Events.” Political Science Research and Methods 10, no. 2 (April 2022): 428–37. https://doi.org/10.1017/psrm.2020.46.

aside:
I never tried whether the PenalizedMixin works with MNLogit, my usual example cases were GLM, Poisson and Logit.

forkee.name: statsmodels

issue.title: ENH: MNLogit identification with categorical variables
issue.body:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/77352027/mnlogit-summary-return-a-array-with-a-lot-of-nan

My guess would be that if we have categorical variables, then we need observations for each endog/exog-cat cell.
But I'm not sure what identification condition we need.

possible workaround:
add option `hessian_pinv=True` to use pinv for hessian that is only semi-definite but not positive definite.

issue.title: anova_lm

milestone.description: Issues and PRs that need to be resolved for a v0.11 release.

issue.body:
Hi,
In the analysis of multivariate regression, anova_lm method throws Exception when the number of factors in x is greater than the number of observations in that factor

#### python code
mod = sfa.ols(function,data=dataf)
fit_result = mod.fit()
aov_table = sa.stats.anova_lm(fit_result, typ=1)

#### When I have more columns than rows,  I have this:
18 is # of factors, 16 is # of observation
shapes (18,18) and (16,) not aligned: 18 (dim 1) != 16 (dim 0)

#### This returns the number of observations rather than the number of factors      
q,r = np.linalg.qr(exog)

With the same input, R can produce the correct results.
Thanks.

comment.body:
I was having this problem myself and @josef-pkt's comment

> IIUC, you have more explanatory variables and parameters than observations

made me realize that I had an interaction term between two categorical variables in my model that had as many distinct combinations than there were observations. Removing that term solved everything. Thanks!

issue.title: Improved performance of the ConditionalMNLogit class
issue.body:
- [x] tests added / passed. 
- [x] code/documentation is well formatted.  
- [x] properly formatted commit message. See [NumPy's guide](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.15.1/dev/gitwash/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message). 

[ConditionalMNLogit](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/main/statsmodels/discrete/conditional_models.py) class: In `loglike` method replaces the nested loop with numpy vector operations. In  `score` method, variable `v` is calculated at a time for the selected values (exp_sum). The number 'p' is used to access them.

As a result, `test_conditional_mnlogit_grad `is calculated 2.7 times faster, and `test_conditional_mnlogit_2d`, `test_conditional_mnlogit_3d `1.7 times faster.

I separated `test_conditional_`, `conditional_models_` into separate files so that I could run the old and new options locally together for comparison (located them in a common directory). In conditional_models there are two classes `ConditionalMNLogit` and `ConditionalMNLogit_new` - in which I made improvements. In tests, the module is connected directly to use both options for tests. `n = 90` is passed `to gen_mnlogit(n)`

Below is the `test_conditional_` code. The `conditional_models_` code is not posted due to line limitations, I am attaching it as an attachment.

<details>

<summary>test_conditional_  - code</summary>

```
import numpy as np
from conditional_models_ import ConditionalMNLogit, ConditionalMNLogit_new
from statsmodels.tools.numdiff import approx_fprime
from numpy.testing import assert_allclose
import pandas as pd


def gen_mnlogit(n):
    np.random.seed(235)

    g = np.kron(np.ones(5), np.arange(n // 5))
    x1 = np.random.normal(size=n)
    x2 = np.random.normal(size=n)
    xm = np.concatenate((x1[:, None], x2[:, None]), axis=1)
    pa = np.array([[0, 1, -1], [0, 2, -1]])
    lpr = np.dot(xm, pa)
    pr = np.exp(lpr)
    pr /= pr.sum(1)[:, None]
    cpr = pr.cumsum(1)
    y = 2 * np.ones(n)
    u = np.random.uniform(size=n)
    y[u < cpr[:, 2]] = 2
    y[u < cpr[:, 1]] = 1
    y[u < cpr[:, 0]] = 0

    df = pd.DataFrame({"y": y, "x1": x1,
                       "x2": x2, "g": g})
    return df


def test_conditional_mnlogit_grad_new(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    model = ConditionalMNLogit_new.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2", groups="g", data=df)

    # Compare the gradients to numeric gradients
    for _ in range(5):
        za = np.random.normal(size=4)
        grad = model.score(za)
        ngrad = approx_fprime(za, model.loglike)
        assert_allclose(grad, ngrad, rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-3)


def test_conditional_mnlogit_grad(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    model = ConditionalMNLogit.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2", groups="g", data=df)

    # Compare the gradients to numeric gradients
    for _ in range(5):
        za = np.random.normal(size=4)
        grad = model.score(za)
        ngrad = approx_fprime(za, model.loglike)
        assert_allclose(grad, ngrad, rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-3)


def test_conditional_mnlogit_2d_new(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    model = ConditionalMNLogit_new.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2", groups="g", data=df)
    result = model.fit()

    #"""
    # Regression tests
    assert_allclose(
        result.params,
        np.asarray([[0.75592035, -1.58565494],
                    [1.82919869, -1.32594231]]),
        rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-5)
    assert_allclose(
        result.bse,
        np.asarray([[0.68099698, 0.70142727],
                    [0.65190315, 0.59653771]]),
        rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-5)
    #"""


def test_conditional_mnlogit_2d(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    model = ConditionalMNLogit.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2", groups="g", data=df)
    result = model.fit()

    # Regression tests
    #"""
    assert_allclose(
        result.params,
        np.asarray([[0.75592035, -1.58565494],
                    [1.82919869, -1.32594231]]),
        rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-5)
    assert_allclose(
        result.bse,
        np.asarray([[0.68099698, 0.70142727],
                    [0.65190315, 0.59653771]]),
        rtol=1e-5, atol=1e-5)
    #"""


def test_conditional_mnlogit_3d_new(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    df["x3"] = np.random.normal(size=df.shape[0])
    model = ConditionalMNLogit_new.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2 + x3", groups="g", data=df)
    result = model.fit()

    #"""
    # Regression tests
    assert_allclose(
        result.params,
        np.asarray([[0.729629, -1.633673],
                    [1.879019, -1.327163],
                    [-0.114124, -0.109378]]),
        atol=1e-5, rtol=1e-5)

    assert_allclose(
        result.bse,
        np.asarray([[0.682965, 0.60472],
                    [0.672947, 0.42401],
                    [0.722631, 0.33663]]),
        atol=1e-5, rtol=1e-5)

    #"""

    # Smoke test
    result.summary()


def test_conditional_mnlogit_3d(n):
    df = gen_mnlogit(n)
    df["x3"] = np.random.normal(size=df.shape[0])
    model = ConditionalMNLogit.from_formula(
        "y ~ 0 + x1 + x2 + x3", groups="g", data=df)
    result = model.fit()

    #"""
    # Regression tests
    assert_allclose(
        result.params,
        np.asarray([[0.729629, -1.633673],
                    [1.879019, -1.327163],
                    [-0.114124, -0.109378]]),
        atol=1e-5, rtol=1e-5)

    assert_allclose(
        result.bse,
        np.asarray([[0.682965, 0.60472],
                    [0.672947, 0.42401],
                    [0.722631, 0.33663]]),
        atol=1e-5, rtol=1e-5)

    #"""

    # Smoke test
    result.summary()

import datetime

n = 90

arr = [[test_conditional_mnlogit_grad_new,
        test_conditional_mnlogit_grad,
        'test_conditional_mnlogit_grad'],
       [test_conditional_mnlogit_2d_new,
        test_conditional_mnlogit_2d,
        'test_conditional_mnlogit_2d'],
       [test_conditional_mnlogit_3d_new,
        test_conditional_mnlogit_3d,
        'test_conditional_mnlogit_3d']]

for i in arr:
    print(i[2]) # name of the called function

    now = datetime.datetime.now()
    i[1](n)
    time_old = datetime.datetime.now() - now

    now = datetime.datetime.now()
    i[0](n)
    time_new = datetime.datetime.now() - now

    print(f'time_old = {time_old}, time_new = {time_new}, '
          f'time_old/time_new = {time_old/time_new}')

    print()
```


</details>

[conditional_models_.py.tar.gz](https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/files/13063756/conditional_models_.py.tar.gz)

Output:
```
n = 90

test_conditional_mnlogit_grad 
time_old = 0:00:00.680232, time_new = 0:00:00.236433, time_old/time_new = 2.8770603088401367
test_conditional_mnlogit_2d
time_old = 0:00:01.908332, time_new = 0:00:01.057139, time_old/time_new = 1.8051855054065737
test_conditional_mnlogit_3d
time_old = 0:00:02.635174, time_new = 0:00:01.468636, time_old/time_new = 1.7943002895203441

n = 2000 # with assert commented 

test_conditional_mnlogit_grad 
time_old = 0:00:16.267467, time_new = 0:00:06.169248, time_old/time_new = 2.636863844669561
test_conditional_mnlogit_2d
time_old = 0:00:45.773023, time_new = 0:00:25.878624, time_old/time_new = 1.768757991151307
test_conditional_mnlogit_3d
time_old = 0:00:57.176253, time_new = 0:00:33.577012, time_old/time_new = 1.7028392222631366
```

<details>

<summary>**Notes**</summary>


* It is essential that you add a test when making code changes. Tests are not 
  needed for doc changes.
* When adding a new function, test values should usually be verified in another package (e.g., R/SAS/Stata).
* When fixing a bug, you must add a test that would produce the bug in main and
  then show that it is fixed with the new code.
* New code additions must be well formatted. Changes should pass flake8. If on Linux or OSX, you can
  verify you changes are well formatted by running 
  ```
  git diff upstream/main -u -- "*.py" | flake8 --diff --isolated
  ```
  assuming `flake8` is installed. This command is also available on Windows 
  using the Windows System for Linux once `flake8` is installed in the 
  local Linux environment. While passing this test is not required, it is good practice and it help 
  improve code quality in `statsmodels`.
* Docstring additions must render correctly, including escapes and LaTeX.

</details>

I tried making changes to the installed library locally and running the test_conditional tests and they passed successfully.
